Melanoma.Name: Melanoma
Melanoma.Risk: Melanoma, the most serious type of skin cancer, develops in the cells (melanocytes) that produce melanin the pigment that gives your skin its color.
Melanoma.Treatment: surgical removal, or excision, of the primary melanoma on the skin.

Actinic keratosis.Advice: If you have more than 1 patch causing you problems such as pain and itchiness, treatment is usually recommended.
Actinic keratosis.Diagnosis: dry scaly patches of skin that have been damaged by the sun
Actinic keratosis.Name: Actinic keratosis
Actinic keratosis.Risk: The patches are not usually serious. But there's a small chance they could become skin cancer, so it's important to avoid further damage to your skin.
Actinic keratosis.Treatment: prescripted creams and gels, freezing the patches (cryotherapy), photodynamic therapy (PDT).

Basal cell carcinoma.Name: Basal cell carcinoma
Basal cell carcinoma.Risk: For most people, basal cell carcinoma is not life-threatening. This skin cancer tends to grow slowly. It spreads to other body part if left untreared.
Basal cell carcinoma.Treatment: Curettage and electrodesiccation (electrosurgery),Radiation therapy, Excisional surgery.

Dermatofibroma.Name: Dermatofibroma
Dermatofibroma.Risk: A dermatofibroma is harmless and seldom causes any symptoms. Usually, only reassurance is needed.
Dermatofibroma.Treatment: Diagnostic excision or skin biopsy is undertaken if there is rapid enlargement.

Vascular lesion.Name: Vascular lesion
Vascular lesion.Risk: Vascular lesion are the mostly unrisky type of vascular lesion in children They are benign, or noncancerous, tumors of the cells that line blood vessels.
Vascular lesion.Treatment: Patients may be placed on medications such as oral corticosteroids like prednisone or propranolol.

Acne.Advice: Consult with a dermatologist for proper diagnosis and treatment
Acne.Name: Acne
Acne.Risk: Acne can lead to scarring and have a significant impact on a person's self-esteem.
Acne.Treatment: Treatment options include topical creams, oral medications, and lifestyle changes such as maintaining a proper skincare routine and avoiding certain triggers.

Eczema.Name: Eczema
Eczema.Risk: Eczema can be associated with other allergic conditions such as asthma and hay fever.
Eczema.Treatment: Topical corticosteroids, moisturizers, antihistamines, and avoiding triggers that can worsen symptoms.

Melanocytic nevus.Advice: Regularly monitor the nevus and consult with a dermatologist if there are any changes
Melanocytic nevus.Diagnosis: Can be diagnosed through visual examination and dermoscopy
Melanocytic nevus.Name: Melanocytic nevus
Melanocytic nevus.Risk: Melanocytic nevi are generally harmless, but they can rarely develop into melanoma.
Melanocytic nevus.Treatment: Most melanocytic nevi do not require treatment. However, if there are any concerning features, the nevus may be removed surgically.
